hobby.message: I hear analog photography still survives in your hands.
Got a new origami fold in your pocket?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Colder, yes. People keep their distance.
I fold origami when it gets tense.
Even scrap paper's hard to find now.
Everyone seems careful who’s watching.
Feels colder, not the weather. People's faces have changed.
I do complex origami—helps pass quiet hours.
Hard to focus lately after all that chaos with the BCI.
Paper models get crushed easier than I thought.
It feels colder since the chaos with the scores began.
I fold origami—dragons, cranes, complicated things. Keeps my hands busy.
When the city shut down, supplies vanished. Even paper got scarce.
Saw my neighbor watch me fold last week, first time anyone noticed.
Feels like small distractions matter more now, somehow.
Harder to relax when rules keep shifting.
Yes, much colder. Trust's evaporated since those score resets; everyone's wary now.
I fold intricate origami from whatever scrap I find.
After the equalization, shared some cranes with neighbors for comfort.
Used to be no one cared what I did, but lately people watch.
The hobby's more than distraction now. It helps me stay calm—focused.
Once I was blamed for a BCI glitch; folding kept me grounded.
Feels strange sharing little gifts in a city so divided.
Colder, definitely. After the score reset fiasco, you feel it in every gesture.
I fold complex origami—mostly dragons, sometimes modular stars—just to keep the panic at bay.
Been folding since I was a kid. Only hobby that feels safe now.
After the equal scores day, I gave cranes to people waiting in my block's lobby.
We all felt human for an hour. Then the system clamped down and the silence returned.
With a low BCI like mine, hobbies are the last refuge—almost subversive to keep one.
I started folding in secret after my access dropped. Paper’s more precious now than credits.
Sometimes I think these small creations last longer than our liberties.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Origami helps. Keeps me focused.
Complicated folds are better than most distractions.
Everyone suddenly friendly after the equalization glitch. Unsettling.
You can't count on calm for long here.
Mostly, I try not to stand out.
Origami's good for steady hands, quiet mind.
That day with the universal access—everyone smiled for once. Weird feeling.
I usually fold at home, hidden. It attracts less notice.
Now people stare more, after things snapped back.
Paper got more valuable since the riots. Even scraps.
It does help, yes. Folding gives my head somewhere safe to go.
During the equal score chaos, I made a bunch just sitting with neighbors.
Funny—people opened up over a crane or frog during those hours.
After lockdown, it felt riskier. Eyes on me again.
I keep my models small. Easy to hide if needed.
Most days it's the only thing that doesn't change.
Definitely helps me dodge the spiral. Precision calms my nerves.
That equalization glitch? Folded a rare tessellation right at my window. Felt free.
Shared a model in the lobby—people actually talked to me for once.
For a moment, my hands stopped shaking when I folded.
But it went back, all at once. Same old vigilance required.
Now, I ration paper like it's currency. Too many eyes wandering.
Sometimes I miss the days when origami was just paper, not hiding.
Absolutely, origami's my circuit-breaker. Quiet, exact, structured. Needed with everything breaking down.
During the equalization glitch, even people I didn't know smiled at my models.
Felt... human, making cranes for strangers who'd never trusted me before.
I always choose complex designs—Ryujin, Kawasaki rose, modular cubes. Keeps my mind too busy for panic.
The city reset so fast. All that openness vanished. Now even folding feels watched.
Had to salvage paper from Council flyers, since stores closed. Scraps everywhere, but at least it's something.
Crazy how a simple fold made people feel equal, just for an hour.
Now, back to isolation. But I keep folding. Can't let the system shape who I am.
Almost got caught with a whole stack of models—had to burn them. Still hurts thinking about it.
